column2: OUT OF NAZARETH
column3: OUT OF NAZARETH

column2: Okochee, in Georgia, had a boom, and J. Pinkney Bloom came out of it with a "wad." Okochee came out of it with a half-million-dollar debt, a two and a half per cent. city property tax, and a city council that showed a propensity for traveling the back streets of the town.
column3: Okochee, in Georgia, had a boom, and j Pinkney Bloom came out of it with a "wad." Okochee came out of it with a half million dollar debt, a two and a half per cent. city property tax, and a city council that showed a propensity for traveling the back streets of the town.

column2: These things came about through a fatal resemblance of the river Cooloosa to the Hudson, as set forth and expounded by a Northern tourist.
column3: These things came about through a fatal resemblance of the river Cooloosa to the Hudson, as set forth and expounded by a Northern tourist.

column2: Okochee felt that New York should not be allowed to consider itself the only alligator in the swamp, so to speak.
column3: Okochee felt that New York should not be allowed to consider itself the only alligator in the swamp, so to speak.

column2: And then that harmless, but persistent, individual so numerous in the South--the man who is always clamoring for more cotton mills, and is ready to take a dollar's worth of stock, provided he can borrow the dollar--that man added his deadly work to the tourist's innocent praise, and Okochee fell.
column3: And then that harmless, but persistent, individual so numerous in the South-the man who is always clamoring for more cotton mills, and is ready to take a dollar's worth of stock, provided he can borrow the dollar-that man added his deadly work to the tourist's innocent praise, and Okochee fell.

column2: The Cooloosa River winds through a range of small mountains, passes Okochee and then blends its waters trippingly, as fall the mellifluous Indian syllables, with the Chattahoochee.
column3: The Cooloosa River winds through a range of small mountains, passes Okochee and then blends its waters trippingly, as fall the mellifluous Indian syllables, with the Chattahoochee.

column2: Okochee rose, as it were, from its sunny seat on the post-office stoop, hitched up its suspender, and threw a granite dam two hundred and forty feet long and sixty feet high across the Cooloosa one mile above the town.
column3: Okochee rose, as it were, from its sunny seat on the post office stoop, hitched up its suspender, and threw a granite dam two hundred and forty feet long and sixty feet high across the Cooloosa one mile above the town.

column2: Thereupon, a dimpling, sparkling lake backed up twenty miles among the little mountains.
column3: Thereupon, a dimpling, sparkling lake backed up twenty miles among the little mountains.

column2: Thus in the great game of municipal rivalry did Okochee match that famous drawing card, the Hudson.
column3: Thus in the great game of municipal rivalry did Okochee match that famous drawing card, the Hudson.

column2: It was conceded that nowhere could the Palisades be judged superior in the way of scenery and grandeur.
column3: It was conceded that nowhere could the Palisades be judged superior in the way of scenery and grandeur.

column2: Following the picture card was played the ace of commercial importance.
column3: Following the picture card was played the ace of commercial importance.

column2: Fourteen thousand horsepower would this dam furnish.
column3: Fourteen thousand horsepower would this dam furnish.

column2: Cotton mills, factories, and manufacturing plants would rise up as the green corn after a shower.
column3: Cotton mills, factories, and manufacturing plants would rise up as the green corn after a shower.

column2: The spindle and the flywheel and turbine would sing the shrewd glory of Okochee.
column3: The spindle and the flywheel and turbine would sing the shrewd glory of Okochee.

column2: Along the picturesque heights above the lake would rise in beauty the costly villas and the splendid summer residences of capital.
column3: Along the picturesque heights above the lake would rise in beauty the costly villas and the splendid summer residences of capital.

column2: The naphtha launch of the millionaire would spit among the romantic coves; the verdured hills would take formal shapes of terrace, lawn, and park.
column3: The naphtha launch of the millionaire would spit among the romantic coves; the verdured hills would take formal shapes of terrace, lawn, and park.

column2: Money would be spent like water in Okochee, and water would be turned into money.
column3: Money would be spent like water in Okochee, and water would be turned into money.

column2: The fate of the good town is quickly told.
column3: The fate of the good town is quickly told.

column2: Capital decided not to invest.
column3: Capital decided not to invest.

column2: Of all the great things promised, the scenery alone came to fulfilment.
column3: Of all the great things promised, the scenery alone came to fulfilment.

column2: The wooded peaks, the impressive promontories of solemn granite, the beautiful green slants of bank and ravine did all they could to reconcile Okochee to the delinquency of miserly gold.
column3: The wooded peaks, the impressive promontories of solemn granite, the beautiful green slants of bank and ravine did all they could to reconcile Okochee to the delinquency of miserly gold.

column2: The sunsets gilded the dreamy draws and coves with a minting that should charm away heart-burning.
column3: The sunsets gilded the dreamy draws and coves with a minting that should charm away heart burning.

column2: Okochee, true to the instinct of its blood and clime, was lulled by the spell.
column3: Okochee, true to the instinct of its blood and clime, was lulled by the spell.

column2: It climbed out of the arena, loosed its suspender, sat down again on the post-office stoop, and took a chew.
column3: It climbed out of the arena, loosed its suspender, sat down again on the post office stoop, and took a chew.

column2: It consoled itself by drawling sarcasms at the city council which was not to blame, causing the fathers, as has been said, to seek back streets and figure perspiringly on the sinking fund and the appropriation for interest due.
column3: It consoled itself by drawling sarcasms at the city council which was not to blame, causing the fathers, as has been said, to seek back streets and figure perspiringly on the sinking fund and the appropriation for interest due.

column2: The youth of Okochee--they who were to carry into the rosy future the burden of the debt--accepted failure with youth's uncalculating joy. For, here was sport, aquatic and nautical, added to the meagre round of life's pleasures.

column3: Girls wore silk waists embroidered with anchors in blue and pink.

column2: The trousers of the young men widened at the bottom, and their hands were proudly calloused by the oft-plied oar. Fishermen were under the spell of a deep and tolerant joy.

column2: Sailboats and rowboats furrowed the lenient waves, popcorn and ice-cream booths sprang up about the little wooden pier.
column3: Sailboats and rowboats furrowed the lenient waves, popcorn and ice cream booths sprang up about the little wooden pier.

column2: Two small excursion steamboats were built, and plied the delectable waters.

column2: Okochee philosophically gave up the hope of eating turtle soup with a gold spoon, and settled back, not ill content, to its regular diet of lotus and fried hominy. And out of this slow wreck of great expectations rose up J. Pinkney Bloom with his "wad" and his prosperous, cheery smile.

column2: Needless to say J. Pinkney was no product of Georgia soil.
column3: Needless to say j Pinkney was no product of Georgia soil.

column2: He came out of that flushed and capable region known as the "North." He called himself a "promoter"; his enemies had spoken of him as a "grafter"; Okochee took a middle course, and held him to be no better nor no worse than a "Yank."
column3: He came out of that flushed and capable region known as the "North." He called himself a "promoter"; his enemies had spoken of him as a "grafter"; Okochee took a middle course, and held him to be no better nor no worse than a "Yank."

column2: Far up the lake--eighteen miles above the town--the eye of this cheerful camp-follower of booms had spied out a graft.
column3: Far up the lake-eighteen miles above the town-the eye of this cheerful camp follower of booms had spied out a graft.

column2: He purchased there a precipitous tract of five hundred acres at forty-five cents per acre; and this he laid out and subdivided as the city of Skyland--the Queen City of the Switzerland of the South.
column3: He purchased there a precipitous tract of five hundred acres at forty five cents per acre; and this he laid out and subdivided as the city of Skyland-the Queen City of the Switzerland of the South.

column2: Streets and avenues were surveyed; parks designed; corners of central squares reserved for the "proposed" opera house, board of trade, lyceum, market, public schools, and "Exposition Hall." The price of lots ranged from five to five hundred dollars.
column3: Streets and avenues were surveyed; parks designed; corners of central squares reserved for the "proposed" opera house, board of trade, lyceum, market, public schools, and "Exposition Hall." The price of lots ranged from five to five hundred dollars.

column2: Positively, no lot would be priced higher than five hundred dollars.
column3: Positively, no lot would be priced higher than five hundred dollars.

column3: One last trip he was making to Skyland before departing to other salad fields.

column3: There was a little business there to be settled-the postmaster was to be paid off for his light but lonely services, and the "inhabitants" had to be furnished with another month's homely rations, as per agreement.

column2: And then Skyland would know J. Pinkney Bloom no more.

column3: The owners of these precipitous, barren, useless lots might come and view the scene of their invested credulity, or they might leave them to their fit tenants, the wild hog and the browsing deer.

column2: Captain MacFarland was at the wheel; therefore it seemed to J. Pinkney Bloom, who was the only other passenger, that it should be his to play the part of host to the boat's new guests, who were, doubtless, on a scenery-viewing expedition.

column2: He stepped forward, with that translucent, child-candid smile upon his fresh, pink countenance, with that air of unaffected sincerity that was redeemed from bluffness only by its exquisite calculation, with that promptitude and masterly decision of manner that so well suited his calling--with all his stock in trade well to the front; he stepped forward to receive Colonel and Mrs. Peyton Blaylock.
column3: He stepped forward, with that translucent, child candid smile upon his fresh, pink countenance, with that air of unaffected sincerity that was redeemed from bluffness only by its exquisite calculation, with that promptitude and masterly decision of manner that so well suited his calling-with all his stock in trade well to the front; he stepped forward to receive Colonel and mrs Peyton Blaylock.

column2: With the grace of a grand marshal or a wedding usher, he escorted the two passengers to a side of the upper deck, from which the scenery was supposed to present itself to the observer in increased quantity and quality.
column3: With the grace of a grand marshal or a wedding usher, he escorted the two passengers to a side of the upper deck, from which the scenery was supposed to present itself to the observer in increased quantity and quality.

column2: There, in comfortable steamer chairs, they sat and began to piece together the random lines that were to form an intelligent paragraph in the big history of little events.
column3: There, in comfortable steamer chairs, they sat and began to piece together the random lines that were to form an intelligent paragraph in the big history of little events.

column2: Our home, sir, said Colonel Blaylock, removing his wide-brimmed, rather shapeless black felt hat, "is in Holly Springs--Holly Springs, Georgia.
column3: Our home, sir, said Colonel Blaylock, removing his wide brimmed, rather shapeless black felt hat, "is in Holly Springs-Holly Springs, Georgia.

column2: I am very proud to make your acquaintance, Mr. Bloom.
column3: I am very proud to make your acquaintance, mr Bloom.

column2: Mrs. Blaylock and myself have just arrived in Okochee this morning, sir, on business--business of importance in connection with the recent rapid march of progress in this section of our state."
column3: mrs Blaylock and myself have just arrived in Okochee this morning, sir, on business-business of importance in connection with the recent rapid march of progress in this section of our state."

column2: The Colonel smoothed back, with a sweeping gesture, his long, smooth, locks.
column3: The Colonel smoothed back, with a sweeping gesture, his long, smooth, locks.

column2: His dark eyes, still fiery under the heavy black brows, seemed inappropriate to the face of a business man.
column3: His dark eyes, still fiery under the heavy black brows, seemed inappropriate to the face of a business man.

column2: He looked rather to be an old courtier handed down from the reign of Charles, and re-attired in a modern suit of fine, but raveling and seam-worn, broadcloth.
column3: He looked rather to be an old courtier handed down from the reign of Charles, and re attired in a modern suit of fine, but raveling and seam worn, broadcloth.

column2: Yes, sir, said Mr. Bloom, in his heartiest prospectus voice, "things have been whizzing around Okochee.

column2: Biggest industrial revival and waking up to natural resources Georgia ever had.
column3: Biggest industrial revival and waking up to natural resources Georgia ever had.

column2: Did you happen to squeeze in on the ground floor in any of the gilt-edged grafts, Colonel?"
column3: Did you happen to squeeze in on the ground floor in any of the gilt edged grafts, Colonel?"

column2: Well, sir, said the Colonel, hesitating in courteous doubt, "if I understand your question, I may say that I took the opportunity to make an investment that I believe will prove quite advantageous--yes, sir, I believe it will result in both pecuniary profit and agreeable occupation."

column2: He has such a talent for financiering and markets and investments and those kind of things.

column2: I think myself extremely fortunate in having secured him for a partner on life's journey--I am so unversed in those formidable but very useful branches of learning."
column3: I think myself extremely fortunate in having secured him for a partner on life's journey-I am so unversed in those formidable but very useful branches of learning."

column2: Colonel Blaylock rose and made a bow--a bow that belonged with silk stockings and lace ruffles and velvet.

column2: Practical affairs, he said, with a wave of his hand toward the promoter, "are, if I may use the comparison, the garden walks upon which we tread through life, viewing upon either side of us the flowers which brighten that journey.
column3: Practical affairs, he said, with a wave of his hand toward the promoter, "are, if I may use the comparison, the garden walks upon which we tread through life, viewing upon either side of us the flowers which brighten that journey.

column2: It is my pleasure to be able to lay out a walk or two.
